awd_titl_txt: Supporting Marine Geoscience Research with ongoing Growth of the Global Multi-Resolution Topography Synthesis and Maintenance of GeoMapApp
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowledge of the depths and morphology of the seafloor is essential for many areas of marine science. The morphology of the seabed provides a record of the diverse geologic processes that affect the submarine environment including volcanic eruptions, faulting, submarine landslides and sediment transport from the continental margins. Detailed seabed bathymetry is also important for other areas of marine science research including evaluation of biological habitats, ocean circulation studies, and prediction of tsunami inundation, as well as for applied studies including fisheries and coastal resource management. Measurements of depth and morphology are now typically achieved through the use of modern swath multibeam echosounders (MBESs). However, the global ocean is vast, and only a small fraction (<15%) of the seafloor has been mapped with direct measurement, and the total area that can be mapped during a typical expedition is very limited. This makes preservation of and easy access to seabed mapping data of high value to the science community. 

MBES data collected during research expeditions funded by the NSF are now routinely archived and accessible through public databases provided by NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information. However, specialist processing is needed to translate the raw expedition data into formats useful for diverse scientific and resource management applications. To help meet this need, the research team has developed the Global Multi-Resolution Topography (GMRT) synthesis which is a unified compilation of spatially sparse, quality controlled gridded MBES data merged with lower resolution global-scale ocean data, high-resolution terrestrial elevation data, and a collection of gridded bathymetry datasets at resolutions of meters to hundreds of meters. GMRT is the only such global synthesis, composed of a suite of multi-resolution grids and images, which at highest resolution preserve the full resolution of the underlying data, as well as attribution and access to source data. GMRT can be accessed through a variety of tools including GeoMapApp (GMA), which is a map-based visualization application that enables users to easily visualize seafloor morphology and make custom maps, as well as to visualize and analyze many other marine data types without the need for specialist expertise. 

Funding for this project supports the continued development and growth of the GMRT synthesis and maintenance of the GMA data visualization and analysis tool. The overall goals of this project are to (1) continue to build the GMRT global synthesis with the processing and integration of new quality controlled MBES coverage from expeditions of the U.S. academic fleet, (2) develop the tools and workflows to enable a distributed mode of GMRT data processing, and the efficient integration of processed MBES data generated by other mapping experts within the science community into the synthesis, (3) provide support for GMA to ensure that this tool is available for GMRT and other data visualization. Broader impacts of this project include greater ease-of-access to marine geoscience data for specialists and non-specialists alike; enhanced research productivity, obviating the need for the time-consuming data processing tasks needed to obtain usable products for scientific inquiry; and facilitating broad re-use of marine geoscience data, which enhances the return on tax-payer investments in ocean science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Knowledge of the morphology of the seafloor is needed for virtually all realms of marine geoscience research as well as for a wide range of other kinds of marine investigations. Measurement of the detailed morphology of the seafloor is typically acquired using specialized sonar systems called multibeam swath sonars, which are now routinely operated on many ocean research expeditions. However, the global ocean is vast, only a small fraction (<15%) of the seafloor has been mapped using multibeam sonars, and the total area that can be ensonified during a typical expedition is very limited, making preservation of and easy access to all acquired seabed mapping data of high value to the science community. The Global Multi-Resolution Topography (GMRT, www.gmrt.org) synthesis is a compilation of processed high-resolution seafloor bathymetry information from the global oceans along with tools for data access, that allow any interested user from the scientific research community to the general public to make and download maps from their specified area of interest. Closely aligned and also designed to support this broad community, the GeoMapApp application (www.geomapapp.org) enables easy visualization of GMRT seafloor morphology to make custom maps, as well as the ability to visualize and analyze many other marine data types (earthquakes, chemical composition of seafloor sediments and rocks, seismic images of sediment layers beneath the seafloor, among other data types) without the need for specialist expertise. GMRT and GeoMapApp both facilitate broad access to marine geoscience data, making specialized data available and accessible to specialists and non-specialists alike. Both services promote data re-use, which enhances the return on tax-payer investments in ocean science, and support research productivity, reducing the need for time-consuming data processing tasks needed to obtain usable products for scientific exploration and inquiry.

During this award period we continued to add new datasets to the GMRT synthesis with five updates (GMRT v3.8-v4.1.1) released over the project period equivalent to a growth in total cumulative trackline length of 18% (to 3.97 million nautical miles of multibeam bathymetry incorporated)  and an increase of 29% in number of cruises included (to a total of 1,426 cruises). We incorporated 2 new releases of the global GEBCO grid into the basemap for the GMRT providing a  factor of 2.5 increase in  resolution (from ~1km to ~400m grid spacing  for GEBCO 2021). We launched a distributable GMRT gridding and tiling package with documentation to enable scientists outside of our group to prepare their multibeam bathymetry data for incorporation into GMRT, thereby streamlining integration of contributions from other groups. We redesigned and optimized the deployment of GMRT in the cloud making use of Amazon Web Services which improved efficiency of data delivery to the user community.  For the GeoMapApp desktop application, we continued to maintain and improve the application with 6 releases over the award period. Global datasets accessible through the application were updated and bug fixes and minor enhancements to the application were made.

An important measure of the success of the project is the amount of usage of both services that is tracked on a monthly basis. Over the project period we tracked increasing usage of the GMRT synthesis, with averages of ~50,000 downloads per month in the last project year compared with 2,000-3,000 downloads a month prior to the start of the award. Most of this growth was through other research data providers using our web services to incorporate the GMRT as the basemap for their own search tools. Usage of the GeoMapApp data visualization application was similar over the project period as in past years with 2,000-5,000 unique users of the application each month. The number of publications in the scientific literature referencing use of the GMRT synthesis and GeoMapApp, an important measure of the usefulness of these services for supporting scientific research, grew by ~27% over the 3-year project period which reflects an ongoing trend of accelerated growth in citations.
